messages.message: I have a simple use-case: a file that has many copies of same doc-type (each doc is 2-3 pages long -- think of 3 statements from Bank of America), and then one another tax form. I have to break it into individual copy of each document (3 bank-of-america statements separated out, and then the tax document separated out).
Split classifier should solve this right?
what do your documents look like? you can try first-page or template classifier. or import ib_classifier_docsplitting from dev exchange in a custom classifier

I recommend looking into `scan_page` or `scan_consecutive_pages` in ibtools
https://github.com/instabase/appengrepo/tree/master/packages/ibtools#scan_page
each uses key phrases to identify matching pages; you can set `return_all` argument to true to return list of all matching page sets

^^^ all great choices. If you’re open to using Koala.classify, here's an example (https://github.com/instabase/appengrepo/blob/master/packages/koala/example.py) of how you might do so.

The idea is to train a `splitter` to learn where to split (pages 1-3 belong together, pages 4-5 belong together, pages 6 is alone, pages 7-9 belong together, etc) and then train a `classifier` to identify the class of each split

e.g.
```scan_page(
    label=['Bank of America', 'Statement'],
    e=1,
    ignorecase=true,
    exclude_label='Tax Form 1234',
    except_e=1,
    return_all=true
)```
@dmitry does scan_page split records in flow?

I used it in the refiner. helpful, if number of similar documents is unknown in advance.  it operates on the ibocr text, rather than records. it is provenance tracked though.
it can be used in the flow as well, although I never tried it before
if I use in refiner I can't show it in human review because of variable number of records
ah, I see. that’s unfortunate, it works really well in Refiner
we had `map_records` split by page_matcher -- does't work anymore
